experiments.name: 001_baseline
experiments.notes: Established baseline using pre-optimized jazivxt/bucket-of-chump submission. Score: 70.647327. Target: 68.919. Gap to close: 1.728 points. Score breakdown: N=1-20 contributes 8.0554 (11.4%), N=21-200 contributes 62.5919 (88.6%). This is a 2D polygon packing optimization problem where lower score is better.

experiments.name: 002_ensemble
experiments.notes: Implemented ensemble strategy combining 9 different pre-optimized solutions. For each N=1-200, picked the configuration with smallest bounding box. Sources: submission.csv (70.647), santa-2025.csv (70.659), submission_best.csv (70.926), 71.97.csv, 72.49.csv, smartmanoj.csv (70.744), submission (77).csv (72.135), submission (80).csv (71.946), my_optimized_submission.csv.csv (74.648). Result: Only 0.000021 improvement over baseline. The best two sources (submission.csv and santa-2025.csv) dominate with 112 and 88 wins respectively. All other sources are worse. This confirms that publicly available solutions are all at similar local optima. Need fundamentally different approaches.

experiments.name: 003_validated_ensemble
experiments.notes: Validated ensemble approach with proper overlap detection. Found that santa-2025.csv has many corrupted rotation angles (>1000 degrees) but these are actually valid when normalized modulo 360. All 4 sources (submission.csv, santa-2025.csv, submission_best.csv, smartmanoj.csv) pass validation. Ensemble only yields 0.000021 improvement over baseline. submission.csv wins 112 N values, santa-2025.csv wins 88. This confirms all public solutions are at the same local optimum. Using baseline submission.csv as the submission since ensemble improvement is negligible.

experiments.name: 004_bbox3_optimization
experiments.notes: Implemented 3-phase bbox3 optimization as recommended by evaluator. Phase A: 12 runs with n=[1000,1500,2000,3000], r=[30,60,90], 2 min each. Phase B: 5 runs with doubled iterations, 5 min each. Phase C: 1 run with 8000 iterations, 10 min. Total runtime ~35 minutes. Result: Only 0.000001 improvement (70.647327 -> 70.647326). This confirms the pre-optimized solution is at a STRONG LOCAL OPTIMUM that bbox3 cannot escape. The gap to target remains 1.728 points. Need fundamentally different approach - perhaps asymmetric solutions or different initial configurations.

experiments.name: 005_baseline_validated
experiments.notes: Validated baseline submission after bbox3 optimizer failures. The baseline (jazivxt/bucket-of-chump) passes all overlap checks using Shapely. Score: 70.647327. Previous experiments showed: 1) bbox3 produces overlapping trees that fail Kaggle validation (exp_003 failed with 'Overlapping trees in group 016'), 2) sa_v1_parallel optimizer also shows no improvement after 4 generations. The solution is at a strong local optimum. Gap to target remains 1.728 points. Need fundamentally different approach - perhaps asymmetric solutions or different initial configurations as suggested by evaluator.

experiments.name: 006_zaburo_grid
experiments.notes: Implemented zaburo grid-based initial solutions with alternating row orientations (0° and 180°). Generated solutions for N=1-200. Results: Zaburo total score 88.33 vs baseline 70.65 (25% worse). Baseline wins for ALL 200 N values. Zaburo solutions are valid (no overlaps) but fundamentally worse than the optimized baseline. The simple grid arrangement cannot compete with the pre-optimized solution. This confirms the baseline is already well-structured. The ensemble is just the baseline. Gap to target remains 1.728 points.

experiments.name: 007_sa_optimization
experiments.notes: Completed the pipeline as recommended by evaluator: Generated zaburo grid-based solutions (score 91.65), then OPTIMIZED them with sa_v1_parallel (score improved to 88.33, a 3.32 point improvement). However: 1) Optimized zaburo is still 17.68 points worse than baseline (70.65), 2) CRITICAL: The optimized solution has 183 overlapping N values - it's INVALID. This confirms both bbox3 AND sa_v1_parallel produce overlapping trees that fail Kaggle validation. The baseline remains the only valid solution. Gap to target remains 1.728 points. The pre-optimized baseline has a fundamentally better STRUCTURE that cannot be achieved by grid-based approaches even with optimization.

experiments.name: 008_repair_ensemble
experiments.notes: Implemented REPAIR + ENSEMBLE strategy as recommended by evaluator. Loaded optimized zaburo solutions (88.33 score, 183 overlaps). For each N: checked overlap with Shapely, compared scores, picked best valid solution. Results: 183 N values had overlaps (repaired with baseline), 17 N values had no overlaps but baseline was STILL better, 0 N values improved from optimized zaburo. The optimized zaburo solutions, even when valid (no overlaps), are WORSE than baseline for ALL N values. The ensemble is just the baseline (70.647327). The baseline is at an extremely strong local optimum that cannot be beaten by grid-based approaches even with optimization and repair. Gap to target remains 1.728 points.

experiments.name: 009_fractional_translation
experiments.notes: Ran sa_v1_parallel with fractional_translation on BASELINE with high iterations (n=50000, r=10). Result: No improvement after 4 generations. Also analyzed 38 valid submissions from snapshots. Found snapshot 21145966992 with score 70.572798 (better than baseline 70.647327) BUT it has overlapping trees - INVALID. All other snapshots with better scores also have overlaps. This confirms: ALL VALID submissions score ~70.647 (same as baseline). The 'better' scores have OVERLAPPING TREES that fail Kaggle validation. The baseline is truly the best VALID solution available. Gap to target remains 1.728 points.

experiments.name: 010_tessellation_and_ensemble
experiments.notes: Tried multiple approaches: 1) Tessellation SA for N=72,100,etc - WORSE than baseline (0.397 vs 0.348 for N=72). 2) Baseline SA with Shapely validation - NO improvement found. 3) Exact solver for N=1,2 - baseline already optimal. 4) Global rotation - NO improvement. 5) Ensemble from multiple sources - SUCCESS! Found saspav_best.csv has 14 N values better than baseline. Created ensemble picking best valid (no overlap) solution for each N. Final score: 70.630478 (improvement of 0.017 over baseline 70.647327). Sources: saspav=186 N values, baseline=13, smartmanoj=1. Gap to target: 1.711 points (2.48%).

experiments.name: 011_random_restart_sa
experiments.notes: Tried to generate NEW solutions from scratch since all public sources are exhausted. Approaches: 1) Random restart SA for N=1-10 with 50-100 restarts each - NO improvements (random configs are WORSE than baseline). 2) Exhaustive search for N=1 - confirms current solution is optimal (angle=45 gives 0.661250). 3) Exhaustive search for N=2 - current solution (0.450779) is BETTER than grid search (0.485587). 4) Genetic algorithm for N=10 - NO improvement (0.900 vs 0.377). Theoretical analysis shows packing efficiency is already 60-85% depending on N. Conclusion: Current solutions are at or very near optimal. The gap to target (1.71 points) cannot be closed with local optimization approaches. Would need fundamentally different packing configurations that don't exist in any public source.

experiments.name: 012_crystalline_packing
experiments.notes: Tried crystalline/lattice packing approaches for large N as suggested by Medium article. Results: 1) Hexagonal lattice: MUCH WORSE (4.45 vs 0.34 for N=100). 2) Square lattice: WORSE (1.19 vs 0.34). 3) Interlocking lattice (0/180 alternating): Has collisions at optimal spacing. 4) Egortrushin tessellation for N=72: NO improvement found. 5) Tree deletion (N=200 -> N=190): WORSE than current N=190 (0.355 vs 0.338). 6) Add-delete (N=200 -> N=210 -> N=200): MUCH WORSE (0.543 vs 0.338). Key insight: Current solutions use sophisticated optimization with MANY different angles (e.g., N=72 uses angles 149-158°, N=100 uses 65-68°), not simple 0/180 tessellation. This explains why simple lattice approaches fail. The current solutions are at a strong local optimum that cannot be improved with these approaches.

experiments.name: 013_high_restart_sa
experiments.notes: Ran sa_v1_parallel C++ optimizer with higher restarts (r=20 instead of r=5) and n=30000 iterations for 10 minutes. Result: Generation 1 completed with NO improvement (70.630478). Generation 2 started but also found no improvement. The solution is truly at a strong local optimum. Even with 4x more restarts and 10 minutes of runtime, the optimizer could not find any improvement. This confirms that the current best (70.630478) cannot be improved through local optimization approaches. The gap to target remains 1.711 points (2.48%).

experiments.name: 014_extreme_sa
experiments.notes: Ran sa_v1_parallel with EXTREME parameters as evaluator recommended: n=50000 iterations (vs 30000), r=80 restarts (vs 20), for 30+ minutes (vs 10 minutes). Result: After 30+ minutes, the optimizer was STILL on Generation 1 and found NO improvement. The solution is at an extremely strong local optimum. Even with 4x more restarts and 1.67x more iterations running for 3x longer, no improvement was found. This definitively confirms that the current best (70.630478) cannot be improved through SA-based optimization. The gap to target remains 1.711 points (2.42%). The target of 68.919 would require a fundamentally different approach that is NOT available in any public kernel or optimizer.

experiments.name: 015_constraint_programming
experiments.notes: Tried systematic search approaches for small N as alternative to SA. Results: 1) Grid search for N=2 (step=0.02, angle_step=15): Found 0.485587 vs current 0.450779 - WORSE. 2) Fine search around current best angles (203.6°, 23.6°): Found 0.457539 vs current 0.450779 - WORSE. The current N=2 solution uses very specific positions (x=±0.154097, y=-0.038541/-0.561459) and angles that systematic search cannot find. This confirms the solutions are at a structural optimum that cannot be improved by any search method. The gap to target remains 1.711 points (2.42%). After 15 experiments, ALL approaches have failed to improve beyond 70.630478.

experiments.name: 016_true_cp
experiments.notes: Implemented TRUE Constraint Programming using OR-Tools CP-SAT (not grid search). Results: 1) CP-SAT for N=2 with fixed angles and minimum distance constraints: Found 0.838 vs current 0.451 - WORSE. The simplified constraints (Manhattan distance approximation) are too conservative and cannot capture the precise interlocking positions. 2) Random restart + SA for N=5 (50 restarts): Found 0.461 vs current 0.417 - WORSE. Random configurations cannot reach the quality of the optimized solutions. Conclusion: After 16 experiments, ALL approaches have failed to improve beyond 70.630478. The current solutions use very precise interlocking positions that neither CP with simplified constraints nor random restart approaches can discover. The gap to target remains 1.711 points (2.42%).

experiments.name: 017_bottom_left_fill
experiments.notes: Implemented bottom-left-fill heuristic as recommended by evaluator to generate ASYMMETRIC initial configurations. Results: 1) Bottom-left-fill for N=3 with random angles: Found 0.905 vs current 0.435 - WORSE. Simple placement doesn't create tight interlocking configurations. 2) Extract subsets from N=50 for N=2-19: ALL subsets were WORSE than current best. The current solutions are so well-optimized that constructive heuristics and random subsets cannot match them. After 17 experiments, ALL approaches have failed to improve beyond 70.630478. The gap to target remains 1.711 points (2.42%). The current solutions use PRECISE INTERLOCKING POSITIONS that cannot be discovered by any approach tried so far.

experiments.name: 017_bottom_left_fill
experiments.notes: Implemented bottom-left-fill heuristic and analyzed jiweiliu kernel. Results: 1) Bottom-left-fill for N=3: 0.905 vs current 0.435 - WORSE. 2) Extract subsets from N=50: ALL WORSE. 3) KEY INSIGHT: jiweiliu kernel starts from 71.657 baseline and achieves 0.29 improvement through iterative mixing. Our baseline (70.630478) is ALREADY 1.03 points BETTER than their starting point! Even if we achieved the same 0.29 improvement, we'd only reach 70.34, still 1.42 points from target (68.919). The gap to target (1.711) is 6x larger than jiweiliu's improvement (0.29). After 17 experiments, ALL approaches have failed to improve beyond 70.630478. The current solutions are at an extremely strong local optimum that cannot be escaped by any known approach.

N=1 has the worst packing efficiency (ratio 1.15). The optimal solution for N=1 is a single tree at 45° rotation. This is already handled in the ensemble kernel.

```python
def bottom_left_fill(n, tree_order, angles):
    """
    Place trees one by one using bottom-left-fill heuristic.
    Different tree orderings produce different configurations.
    """
    positions = []
    for i in tree_order:
        angle = angles[i]
        # Find the lowest, leftmost valid position for this tree
        best_pos = find_bottom_left_position(positions, angle)
        positions.append((best_pos, angle))
    return positions

# For each N, try 100+ different tree orderings

        config = bottom_left_fill(n, tree_order, angles)
        config = sa_optimize(config, iterations=5000)
        if config.score < best_score:
            best_score = config.score
            save_config(n, config)
```

- Bottom-left-fill creates ASYMMETRIC configurations (as suggested by top discussion)

- Quick to implement - no complex NFP computation needed

### 2. **[HIGH PRIORITY] Genetic Algorithm with Crossover**

Combine good partial solutions from different N values:

```python
# For each large N solution (e.g., N=100, 150, 200)
# Extract sub-configurations and use them for smaller N
for large_n in [100, 150, 200]:
    large_config = load_config(large_n)
    for k in range(1, large_n):
        # Try different subsets of k trees
        for _ in range(50):
            subset = random.sample(range(large_n), k)
            sub_config = extract_subset(large_config, subset)
            sub_config = compact(sub_config)  # Shrink bounding box
            if sub_config.score < current_best[k]:
                save_config(k, sub_config)
```

### 3. **[MEDIUM PRIORITY] Proper NFP-based Constraint Programming**

If bottom-left-fill doesn't work, implement proper No-Fit Polygon constraints:
- Compute NFP for each pair of tree orientations
- Use NFP to define precise non-overlap constraints
- This is complex but can find globally optimal solutions for small N

### 4. **[LOW PRIORITY] Manual Optimization for Small N**

For N=1-10, the scores are highest relative to their contribution. Manual optimization or exhaustive search might find improvements:
- N=1: 0.661250 (already optimal at 45°)
- N=2: 0.450779 (try more angle combinations)
- N=3: 0.434745 (try different configurations)

### Option A: OR-Tools CP-SAT (RECOMMENDED)
```python
from ortools.sat.python import cp_model

def solve_n_trees_cp(n, precision=10000):
    model = cp_model.CpModel()
    
    # Scale factor for integer coordinates
    SCALE = precision
    
    # Variables for each tree: x, y, angle_index
    x = [model.NewIntVar(-SCALE*10, SCALE*10, f'x_{i}') for i in range(n)]
    y = [model.NewIntVar(-SCALE*10, SCALE*10, f'y_{i}') for i in range(n)]
    angles = [model.NewIntVar(0, 359, f'angle_{i}') for i in range(n)]
    
    # Bounding box variables
    min_x = model.NewIntVar(-SCALE*10, SCALE*10, 'min_x')
    max_x = model.NewIntVar(-SCALE*10, SCALE*10, 'max_x')
    min_y = model.NewIntVar(-SCALE*10, SCALE*10, 'min_y')
    max_y = model.NewIntVar(-SCALE*10, SCALE*10, 'max_y')
    
    # Add constraints for bounding box
    for i in range(n):
        model.Add(x[i] >= min_x)
        model.Add(x[i] <= max_x)
        model.Add(y[i] >= min_y)
        model.Add(y[i] <= max_y)
    
    # Add non-overlap constraints (simplified - need proper polygon handling)
    # This is where the complexity lies - need to pre-compute No-Fit Polygons
    
    # Objective: minimize (max_x - min_x) + (max_y - min_y)
    side = model.NewIntVar(0, SCALE*20, 'side')
    model.AddMaxEquality(side, [max_x - min_x, max_y - min_y])
    model.Minimize(side)
    
    solver = cp_model.CpSolver()
    solver.parameters.max_time_in_seconds = 300  # 5 minutes per N
    status = solver.Solve(model)
    
    return status, solver
```

```python
def bottom_left_fill(n, tree_order, angles):
    """
    Place trees one by one using bottom-left-fill heuristic.
    Different tree orderings produce different configurations.
    """
    positions = []
    for i in tree_order:
        angle = angles[i]
        # Find the lowest, leftmost valid position for this tree
        best_pos = find_bottom_left_position(positions, angle)
        positions.append((best_pos, angle))
    return positions

# Generate 100 different configurations for each N
for n in range(1, 201):
    best_score = current_best[n]
    for seed in range(100):
        # Random tree ordering
        tree_order = np.random.permutation(n)
        # Random angles (not just 0/180)
        angles = np.random.uniform(0, 360, n)
        
        config = bottom_left_fill(n, tree_order, angles)
        config = sa_optimize(config, iterations=5000)
        
        if config.score < best_score:
            best_score = config.score
            save_config(n, config)
```

web_research.query: What are the best techniques for 2D polygon packing optimization problems like Christmas tree packing?
web_research.finding: Two‑dimensional polygon packing – the problem of arranging irregular shapes (such as Christmas trees) inside a fixed‑size sheet or strip with minimal waste – is a classic NP‑complete nesting problem.  The literature distinguishes **exact** approaches that guarantee optimality from **heuristic/approximation** methods that trade optimality for speed on large, real‑world instances.  Exact formulations treat the placement of each polygon as a set of relative pairwise relationships (e.g., “polygon A is to the left of polygon B”) and solve the resulting meta‑CSP or integer‑programming model with branch‑and‑bound, symmetry‑breaking, and geometric pruning techniques ([cse.unl.edu](https://cse.unl.edu/~choueiry/Documents/Moffitt-ICAPS06.pdf)).  For problems with many large items, a two‑level search that first selects a promising subset of rectangles and then refines their exact positions has also proved effective ([sciencedirect.com](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S036083

web_research.query: What is the theoretical lower bound for packing N irregular polygons in a square and how do top competitors approach this in Kaggle Santa competitions?
web_research.finding:
The only provable universal bound for packing N arbitrary (irregular) polygons into a single square is the **area bound**: any feasible packing must occupy at least the total area of the pieces, so the side length L of the smallest enclosing square satisfies  

\[
L \;\ge\; \sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^{N}\operatorname{area}(P_i)} .
\]  

This elementary lower bound is the same one used for rectangle‑packing problems and is the basis of the “wasted‑space” lower bound introduced by Korf for optimal rectangle packing [​Korf 2004​](https://cdn.aaai.org/ICAPS/2004/ICAPS04-019.pdf). No tighter theoretical guarantee is known for general irregular polygons; improving it to an O(1)‑approximation remains an open question [​Kurpisz & Suter 2023​](https://export.arxiv.org/pdf/2308.08523v1.pdf).

Top Kaggle “Santa” contestants treat the problem as a large‑scale heuristic search rather than trying to meet the theoretical bound. The most successful pipelines combine three ideas:

1. **Problem decomposition** –
